case_title: Commissioner of Income-Tax vs K. C. Rangaiah & Co.

questions_of_law.question: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal is correct in law in cancelling the order passed by the Commissioner of Income-tax under section 263 of the Income Tax Act, 1961?
questions_of_law.answer: Negative, in favour of the Revenue and against the assessee.

questions_of_law.question: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal ought to have held that the Commissioner of Income-tax had jurisdiction to pass orders under section 263 since the facts subsequently revealed showed that the Income-tax Officer did not make proper enquiries when granting registration to the firm?
questions_of_law.answer: Affirmative, in favour of the Revenue and against the assessee.

questions_of_law.question: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal is correct in law in directing that the material available at the time of passing the order under section 263 but which was not available at the time the Income-tax Officer passed the impugned order dated August 29, 1981, under section 185 should be ignored?
questions_of_law.answer: Negative, in favour of the Revenue and against the assessee.

legal_provisions.description: Reference provision for questions of law.
Revision of orders prejudicial to Revenue.

key_points: The Commissioner exercised revisional power under section 263 to cancel the registration granted under section 185.
The Tribunal initially ruled in favor of the assessee, stating the Commissioner could not rely on material unavailable at the time of the Income-tax Officer's order.
The High Court clarified that the Explanation to section 263, inserted by the Finance Act, 1988, is retrospective and allows the Commissioner to rely on material available at the time of examination.
Supreme Court judgments affirmed the wide amplitude of section 263, allowing consideration of subsequent material before revisional power is exercised.
